Perform Correlation Analysis with Comprehensive Diagnostics

Source: R/correlation.R
analyze_correlation.Rd

Calculates correlation coefficients between variables with explicit assumption testing and publication-ready output. Supports Pearson (parametric) and Spearman (non-parametric) correlations.

Usage

analyze_correlation(
  data,
  var1 = NULL,
  var2 = NULL,
  method = "auto",
  check_assumptions = TRUE,
  alpha = 0.05,
  verbose = TRUE
)

Arguments

data

Data frame containing variables, or first numeric vector

var1

Name of first variable (if data is data frame), or NULL

var2

Name of second variable (if data is data frame), or second numeric vector

method

Correlation method: "auto" (default), "pearson", or "spearman"

check_assumptions

Logical. Test assumptions? Default is TRUE

alpha

Significance level (default 0.05)

verbose

Logical. Show detailed explanations? Default is TRUE

Value

A list containing:

  • method: Correlation method used

  • correlation: Correlation coefficient (r or rho)

  • p_value: Statistical significance

  • significant: Is correlation significant?

  • n: Sample size

  • ci_lower: Lower confidence interval (95

  • ci_upper: Upper confidence interval (95

  • strength: Interpretation of correlation strength

  • direction: Positive, negative, or near-zero

  • assumptions: Assumption check results (if requested)

  • publication_text: Publication-ready text

  • interpretation: Plain English interpretation

Details

## Correlation Assumptions:

**Pearson Correlation:**

  • Linearity: Variables have linear relationship

  • Bivariate normality: Both variables normally distributed

  • No outliers: Extreme values can distort correlation

**Spearman Correlation:**

  • Monotonic relationship: Variables increase/decrease together

  • No assumptions about distribution

  • Robust to outliers

## Strength Interpretation (absolute value):

  • 0.00 - 0.10: Negligible

  • 0.10 - 0.30: Weak

  • 0.30 - 0.50: Moderate

  • 0.50 - 0.70: Strong

  • 0.70 - 1.00: Very strong

Examples

# Example 1: Data frame with variable names
data <- data.frame(
  customer_satisfaction = c(7, 8, 6, 9, 5, 8, 7, 6, 9, 8),
  purchase_intention = c(8, 9, 7, 9, 6, 8, 7, 7, 9, 8)
)
result <- analyze_correlation(data, "customer_satisfaction", "purchase_intention")
#> 
#> Checking assumptions for correlation analysis...
#> Assumption checks complete.
#> Auto-selection: Using Pearson correlation (assumptions met)
#> Computing pearson correlation...
#> Correlation analysis complete!

# Example 2: Two numeric vectors
x <- c(23, 45, 67, 34, 56, 78, 89, 12, 45, 67)
y <- c(34, 56, 78, 45, 67, 89, 90, 23, 56, 78)
result <- analyze_correlation(x, var2 = y)
#> 
#> Checking assumptions for correlation analysis...
#> Assumption checks complete.
#> Auto-selection: Using Pearson correlation (assumptions met)
#> Computing pearson correlation...
#> Correlation analysis complete!

# Example 3: Force Spearman (non-parametric)
result <- analyze_correlation(data, "customer_satisfaction",
                               "purchase_intention", method = "spearman")
#> 
#> Checking assumptions for correlation analysis...
#> Assumption checks complete.
#> Computing spearman correlation...
#> Warning: Cannot compute exact p-value with ties
#> Correlation analysis complete!

# View publication text
print(result, show_publication = TRUE)
#>

#> VARIABLES:
#>   Variable 1: customer_satisfaction 
#>   Variable 2: purchase_intention 
#>   Sample size: 10 
#> 
#> CORRELATION:
#>   r = 0.9262 
#>   r^2 = 0.8578 ( 85.8 % shared variance)
#>   p-value: 0.000119 
#>   Significant: YES (p < .05) 
#> 
#> INTERPRETATION:
#>   Strength: very strong 
#>   Direction: positive 
#> 
#> DETAILED INTERPRETATION:
#>   The Spearman correlation between customer_satisfaction and
#>   purchase_intention is very strong and positive (rho = 0.926, n = 10, p =
#>   1e-04). This correlation is statistically significant at alpha = 0.05.
#>   The very strong relationship suggests meaningful covariation between the
#>   variables. Approximately 85.8% of variance in one variable is associated
#>   with variance in the other.
#>

#> 
#> ASSUMPTIONS:
#>   Assumptions of monotonicity and independence, with outliers assessed for
#>   robustness were assessed.
#> 
#> 
#> METHODS:
#>   A Spearman correlation was computed to assess the relationship between
#>   customer_satisfaction and purchase_intention.
#> 
#> 
#> RESULTS:
#>   The correlation was significant (rho(8) = 0.93, p < .001).
#> 
#> 
#> INTERPRETATION:
#>   There was a very strong positive relationship between customer_satisfaction
#>   and purchase_intention.
#> 
#> 
#> ADDITIONAL NOTES:
#>   Correlation strength was interpreted using Cohen's (1988) guidelines. The
#>   correlation coefficient of 0.926 indicates that the variables share
#>   approximately 85.8% common variance (r^2 = 0.858).
#> 
#> 
#> 
#> USAGE NOTE:
#>   Copy the sections above into your manuscript. Modify as needed for your
#>   specific journal's requirements and integrate with your narrative.
#> 
#> 
#> Tip: Use print(result, show_assumptions = TRUE) to see assumption checks
#> Tip: Create a scatterplot to visualize the relationship:
#>       plot(customer_satisfaction, purchase_intention)
#>
